title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for Maine in 2020?
preds: Not over yet but Republican Collins is leading https://www.pressherald.com/2020/11/04/collins-maintaining-lead-over-gideon-in-senate-race/
Staying the same; not all votes counted yet.
Because of ranked choice voting and Biden's double digit lead in the polls. Collins has almost no chance of winning
Tight race. Slight advantage to the Democrats, they have a stronger ground game.
Maine's ranked voting may help the Democrat somewhat: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/10/31/could-maines-ranked-choice-voting-system-cost-sen-susan-collins/
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Change: Gideon (+10) Reasoning: I adhere pretty closely to 538 and they have always been a little tepid on Maine. But after digging in a little more I think that is because they aren't accounting for rank choice voting. The polls are pretty close because the Maine Senate seat also has a firebrand liberal and an independent. However, the liberal, who is getting about 4% is telling all or her supporters to list Sara Gideon as a 2nd choice. Given that wrinkle, I'm adjusting so that this is comparable with Colorado and Arizona.

@LokiOdinevich & @cafebedouin have talked me back into increasing my forecast. They have pointed out that Gideon stands likely to benefit from high voter turnout,  Biden voters, and the ranked voting system.
Gideon doesn't have any momentum.  Collins may pull this out of the bag.  Reducing forecast for Dem.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

RMG Research, Inc. found that 48% of registered voters currently back Democratic challenger Sara Gideon over incumbent Collins, who has 41% support.  11% of registered voters remaining undecided. Momentum is with Gideon.  The 11% undecideds would have to break 91% for Collins. . . very unlikely!!!

They also have ranked choice voting in Maine which makes it even more unlikely Collins will win.

Maine voters typically prefer moderate candidates, and with Collins' history of supporting Trump, who is seen by many to be a far-right leader, and his agenda, which is more polarizing than moderating, it will be difficult for her to finish her bid for reelection with a victory. Biden is up by double-digits (on average) in Maine polls, and her challenger, Gideon, has turned a deficit into a 4-5 point advantage in less than a month. With the climate being what it is, Collins' path to victory will be incredibly difficult given she has less than 3 months left.

Maine has gone Democrat virtually every year in the last few decades in the Presidential and the headlines surrounding the Republican incumbent, Susan Collins, has not been positive over the last few years. Her opponent also has a 4-5 point lead, which he has held for over two months. It could be close, but it is likely going Dem.
Lowering a little for Democratic candidate. It is a very close race in a traditionally conservative state.

4. She has a formidable opponent in Sara Gideon the Maine House Speaker.

Senator Collins is a strong brand in Maine, reportedly mostly owing to effective constituent service.  However, she has run out of wiggle room on policy questions and is subject to the down-ticket tsunami if The Prince Of Orange doesn't carry the state.
Cash on hand is about the same but it will be hard to defeat well know Susan Collins.

Current spread is Gideon to Collins, 44 to 42. Supposing a 6-point error margin between early polling and final vote share, that gives us G ~ Uniform(38,50), C ~ Uniform(36,48). So G - C is distributed triangular, and the probability that G-C > 0 is 65%. So I'm ticking up here for Gideon, with the additional rationale that Collins is an unpopular Senator in the party of an unpopular President.

Change: Dems +25, I have been hesitant betting on Gideon because historically Collins is a survived but every indicator points to a loss for her. While traditionally a state with a large independent street Maine has become very solidly democratic at all levels (statehouse, governor, congressional reps) if the polarization has leaked to that level I have every belief it will exist for a senate election. Additionally, Collins is trailing in the few polls conducted at this point.

Senator Collins has been around a long time, which is both an advantage and the other thing.  Until fairly recently she looked good for reelection; folks generally like her and she has delivered fairly well for Maine.  However, she has been kissing The Current Incumbent on both cheeks a bit too avidly, which may in turn bite her on the nether cheeks in November.  (This seems anatomically impossible, now that I think about it.)  It will be close, I'm pretty sure, but she could plausibly get swept away by a D tsunami, if one does indeed develop.
The general Democrat position has improved of late, and the incumbent is torn between the GOP base and Dem swing voters she's needed to survive this long.
The Dems will align Collins with Trump and it’ll cost her the contest. And put the Dems closer to flipping the Senate.

Maine has gone blue, Collins is the last Republican standing in New England and Biden is up by thirteen points in the state. Unlikely Collins wins in an environment where Republicans are going to go extinct.

Collins is in big trouble for her support of Trump, even though this is still nominally a Republican state. Maine voters stress their independence and this will cost Collins, now seen as a Trump lap dog.

Collins has separated herself from Trump. This will not play well for Trump voters. On the flip side, she won’t be picking up Democratic voters.  I don’t see a clear path to her winning the seat, although her name recognition (most votors vote for names they know) will bring her votes, so it will be close.
Whoever wins, it will be close.
Susan Collins is near impossible to defeat unless health becomes an issue or some dark horse candidate.

It will be close. Southern Maine more liberal, and they forget that they are not all of Maine- I think people are overly optimistic that Susan Collins will be easily defeated. Northern Maine is more conservative and the Republican Party here will fight tooth and nail. Out of state money will go towards both candidates; so far more to the democratic candidate, but closer to the election there will likely be a big flow of funds to Susan Collins. Any hint of gun control will bring out the north to the polls; democratic candidate can’t push too hard on that issue, which will frustrate the more progressive south.

Maine is pretty progressive. Susan Collins has lots of people mad at her, and surprised, she usually is a voice of reason but blew that at the impeachment trial. I think Maine is ready to go blue all the way
Maine is blue but the current environment is going to trigger their Yankee instincts.
Susan Collins is finally going down after being too much of a Trump apologist

Adjusting way down based on historical data. It seems like incumbents with negative net approval do often lose their seats.
Noticed my earlier forecast used old data. Adjusting downwards.

I'm going to start with a base rate of 85% of reelection of the incumbent. Incumbents seem to get reelected pretty regularly even when their disapprovals match closely with approvals: see Tammy Baldwin, Wisconsin incumbent reelected in 2018 with +2% disapproval; Joe Manchin, West Virginia incument reelected with +1%... but Collins is facing 52% disapproval vs 37% approval.  That's 15%! And 1 in 6 incumbents get ejected-- it's a safe bet those are the ones with high disapproval. Still, 538 was showing 47-43 in Gideon's favor, which at that stage is basically even odds. So I'll split the difference between 50 and 85 as a starting point.

Maine has voted Democratic in the past 7 presidential elections. I think it will vote Dem again which will help the Dem candidate, Collins is the most unpopular senator in the country according to MorningConsult and I think Dem enthusiasm/voter turnout will be high in the fall in a referendum election on Trump. I don't think Collins will be able to have enough split-ticket votes to win but she has in the past (2012).

Polls show a toss-up. Gideon has fundraising momentum but Collins has more cash on hand. Cook political and Sabato's call it a toss-up. Gonna lean Dem for now due to reporting about Collins being super unpopular and vulnerable.
Collins did not do herself any favors when she voted for Kavanaugh. While I don't know if Maine will turn completely blue, there are women in both parties who are tired of being an after thought.
Susan Collins is treading water and has a dynamic opponent, such that even in a year not featuring a mass Trump backlash she would be vulnerable.

High % possibility for "other" given Maine's history of electing independents and (in today's world) moderates. Susan Collins seems vulnerable given her vote on Kavanaugh, she's been there a while as well.
Trump is no longer a winning card for teh republicans.
Collins one of the least popular Senators in the country, Maine is shifting toward blue (in presidential elections, at least), Gideon has raised lots of money.

Collins is currently a bit behind in the A and B rated polls per 538. Additionally, the national generic ballot is favoring Democrats. Collins has staked herself out as a moderate, but her siding with Trump in some of the larger battles has made her moderate position appear fake. Biden currently leads Trump significantly in the Maine polls, so as Collins has tied herself to Trump to some extent that may damage her chances. I think her challenger is somewhat more likely to win. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/maine/
Collins has won many races by over 30 points, however, she will be in a very close election this time. This is a race the national DNC has targeted with money and support.

Both surveys show movement since earlier polling of the race, when Collins led Gideon by 16 points in a poll in June 2019. The Republican senator was one of the most popular in the country as recently as 2017, but has seen her approval ratings decline significantly since President Donald Trump took office. The drop has been particularly dramatic among Democrats and independents, from whom Collins has drawn significant support throughout her career, as the Maine senator has fought to maintain her reputation as an independently minded senator in an increasingly polarized era of politics. She became a target for Democrats nationally after her vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court in 2018.
(https://bangordailynews.com/2020/03/05/politics/new-poll-shows-gains-for-sara-gideon-in-tight-senate-race-against-susan-collins/)
Susan Collins has been polling ok in Maine, however, the partisan environment might finally bring her down.

https://www.alternet.org/2020/05/maine-women-are-turning-on-susan-collins-as-she-falls-in-line-with-trumps-gop-not-the-same-thing-anymore/ "Women voters who propelled Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, to wins in four consecutive Senate races have increasingly soured on the so-called “centrist” Republican as her record has drifted farther right since President Donald Trump’s election. Maine is a uniquely women-dominated state. About 77% of women residents are registered to vote, and 65% of women voters turn out on Election Day, both the highest marks in the nation according to Politico. Collins won past elections with more than 60% support from women, but recent polls have found that more than 60% of women voters oppose her reelection. Her support among women voters under 50 has fallen to just 25%".
Susan Collins have failed to represent her states peoples interests and views.

@jayb Thanks for your research  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1030925 I think that this is an interesting race to watch.  Susan Collins is best friends with Alaska's most effective senator, Lisa Murkowski. Lisa was "primaried".  Thinking her ultra-conservative Republic opponent was not a threat, she didn't campaign much during the primary and lost!  Some Democrats and others convinced her that she was electable if she ran as an independent write-in candidate.  Given that she doesn't have a common last name, would be a write-in, and was running against party candidates, it was a long-shot, but she won.  Now, if something like that happens in Maine, that would mean "Someone else" would be the winner.  Right?   I'm wondering how Maine voters rank DJT.  A Democratic senatorial candidate might out-poll the Democratic presidential candidate if folks think that it's important to flip the Senate, regardless, or because of who might win the WH. EDIT:  I'm thinking that we have to keep in mind that COVID is/could be a black swan this election cycle.   What if one of these candidates got a severe case of it and either was unable to campaign or died?

The Democratic candidate had a small lead in a couple of early polls but most 'pundits' currently rate this contest as a toss-up.
